title: Thieves pretending to be wealthy Arab tourists burgled hotel rooms in Paris
text:
10 shares 3
View
comments
Thieves posing as wealthy Arab tourists who used a stethoscope to check hotel rooms were empty before ransacking them, have been arrested by French police.
The orchestrated crime began when the two men told reception staff that they had lost their room keys, and were granted access to Arab holidaymakers' rooms in luxury hotels in Paris and the French Riviera.
Before they entered the rooms, the pair, believed to be 56 and 31 years old, used a stethoscope on the door to check there was nobody inside, before entering.
French police swooped to arrest two men who dressed as 'wealthy Arab tourists' in order to burgle high-end hotel rooms in Paris
They then removed the safes using a hammer and chisel, before placing them in suitcases to waiting transportation outside the hotel, reports eturbonews .
Crimes had been reported in a number of high-end hotels, and the men were caught after police took CCTV footage taken at the time of the incidents.

Share this article Share France’s RTL radio has said that the police recovered jewellery, luxury clothing and varied Arab currency worth Dhs 328,534 (£60,000) among the suspects’ possessions.
The thieves also had about 20 hotel key cards.
Paris is a popular spot in the summer months for holidaymakers from a number of destinations across the Middle East
During the summer months, European economy is stimulated by the spending of wealthy Arabs taking their holidays.
The government in the UAE has previously warned people travelling to Europe to be on their guard against crime, saying that possessions should be kept hidden and secure.
Tourists are advised to research the cities they are travelling to, and acknowledge local laws and customs.
